body.p: Welcome to Stencila! This article gives you a quick overview of Stencila's features. With Stencila you can author standardised reproducible publications. It features a word processor and spreadsheet editor, designed specifically for research.

sec.title: Code Cells
sec.p: In Stencila you can insert code cells, which produce a computed output.
Cells can be assigned to a variable for later reuse. Stencila analyses the dependencies between cells, so it can perform the minimal update, making computation fast and responsive.

By default, cells are written in a simple expression language called Mini. Mini is equivalent to Excel formulas and includes a standard function library that provides the most common mathematical and statistical methods.

sec.title: Source Data
sec.p: In Stencila datasets are part of the publication. Use the tabs in the status bar to switch to the spreadsheet editor and reveal the source data. Data can be referenced from a spreadsheet and assigned a variable.
Now we are able to do some analysis. Note that you are able to change the data in the spreadsheet and it will have an immediate effect in the article.

sec.title: Plotting
sec.p: Stencila provides a wrapper function around Plotly, a powerful Javascript plotting library. Please see the Plotly documentation for usage.

sec.title: Custom Code
sec.p: Sometimes only using predefined functions is not enough and you want to write a custom piece of code. The following piece of Javascript is there just to convert Stencila's native table data structure into Plotly's surface data format.
Now we can pass the data to Plotly to render an interactive 3D-Chart.

sec.title: External Languages
sec.p: The purpose of this example document is to exemplify the fundamental concepts of Stencila. We chose to only use Mini and Javascript cells in this guide, since this means it can run entirely in the browser.
However, in Stencila you are able to use other languages as well, including Python, R and SQL. We'll follow up shortly with additional guides for those.
